title.narrative: Strengthening Youth Entrepreneurship

participating-org.narrative: Fourah Bay College, University of Sierra Leone

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Entrepreneurial University Transformation training in Sierra Leone

Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

title.narrative: Narrative report

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative: Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period. + In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

actual.value:
Entrepreneurship as a standalone module in the new FBC curriculum was scheduled as a year 5 module; with the original intention of offering in the 2020/21 academic year. Staff were, however, not trained in delivering entrepreneurship education and performing entrepreneurial teaching. The TMT remedied this by building competence in terms of entrepreneurship knowledge, skills and attitudes. The strategy was to obtain a core group of trained personnel in the area of entrepreneurship first and then cascade the training down to the lower years in the Faculty programme. The TMT intervention did, as anticipated, facilitate this capacity building process of obtaining that critical mass of trained personnel who will train others. In addition, the TMT helped the FBC to strengthen its strategic process of becoming more entrepreneurial.
_**Lessons learned**_
· A key lesson is that the design and organization of online education should start early in the lifespan of a project.
· The pandemic has shown that project risk management is fundamental and necessary in the design stage of a project with risk mitigating actions clearly identified.
· Due to the uncertainty of the duration of the pandemic there was some “wait and see” when at least the option of a blended learning approach entailing an online first phase would have resulted in reduced time compression in the final months.
· The recruitment of highly experienced expertise, including management of the online learning environment, certainly helped to capture the attention and interest of the participants.
· The training was linked to the formulation and enhancement of operational plans enabling a clear strategic alignment for the program which promoted interest and participation.
· Shorter phased online training sessions, combined with group and individual assignments during the week, served to maintain a high level of interest, minimize conflicting time demands and organize learning into manageable bite-sized chaunks.
· Stakeholder collaboration can disseminate learning beyond the project partner and strengthen future collobarative platforms.
_**Recommendations**_
· The project partner, FBC, made effective use of the TMT to advance its strategy and merits continuing donor support.
· Whilst FBC faculty have enhanced knowledge and skills on entrepreneurship, it should be noted that it is firstly a cross-cutting topic, and secondly, that the University of Sierra Leone Business School participated in the facilitation of the training and should be a partner in the continuing development of the entrepreneurial university.
· Notwithstanding the covid-19 pandemic, online education and training is here to stay and should be an option, at least in a blended learning design, in future similar TMT.
· The TMT program is a useful and flexible mechanism for building capacity aligned with key country priorities; it has resource limitations but should remain available as a tool for development.

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value:
_**Output 1: An entrepreneurial transformation plan for the Fourah Bay College and the Faculty of Engineering and Architecture in particular**_
By agreement it what was decided to combine the Entrepreneurial Transformation Plan (output 1) with the Operational Plan for setting up a Centre for Innovation and Entrepreneurship (output 2) in one document. The reason for this is that FBC has recently set up an Innovation Hub, which included some support provided under a DFID funded project for FBC. The TMT team, led by Dr. Paul Engel, collaborated with the lead consultant from the DFID project and provided further technical advice on the strengthening of the Innovation Hub within the framework of the entrepreneurial university and overall goal of strengthening youth entrepreneurship in Sierra Leone.
‘Transformation’ was a key word in the program, in effect _sine qua non_ to the development of an entrepreneurial university. Accordingly, the TMT team paid permanent attention to transformative organisational processes and change management. A specific training session on institutional transformation was also conducted as well as an additional training session on diversity and inclusion was conducted by Dr. Mo Solomon. The latter was considered an important aspect of transformational change. The TMT team believes that ten of the participant group represent a strong core, regarded as change champions, who will provide a driving force for institutional transformation into the future.
_**Output 2: An operational plan for setting up a Centre for Innovation and Entrepreneurship**_
Dr. Engel’s TMT sessions were focused on ‘Reading the Business Innovation Eco-System’ and ‘Strengthening the Innovation Hub at FBC.’ These further served to provide a way forward for the Innovation Hub in six strategic implementation steps:
1. Strategically position the Hub by linking with current policy objectives
2. Establish a clear profile and visibility by defining the Hub’s primary aim and focus
3. Define the instruments that the Hub is going to apply and their costs
4. Define the facilities that the University provides to the Hub and their costs
5. Define knowledge management, networking and learning strategies for key areas
6. Build learn and highlight track record noting the Hub is not starting from scratch.
_**Output 3: The curriculum for an entrepreneurship education program for students**_
All TMT sessions included key topics for inspiring the entrepreneurship curriculum; three were conducted specifically by Dr. Meine Pieter van Dijk, and included lessons from startups as well as comparative analysis of transitions at other fairly similar universities that aimed to become an entrepreneurial university. Dr. Engel contributed lectures on the role of partnership and networking in mobilising and transforming the FBC business (innovation) ecosystem. Emphasis was put on mainstreaming entrepreneurship in the curriculum as well as the sub-topics relating to Entrepreneurship as a standalone course. The approach in the training was not prescriptive, but drew from good practice in such a way that FBC curriculum developers can use a range of materials, approaches and case examples to build the curriculum. Topics covered in the training included individual level focus on the young entrepreneur:
• How to start your business
• About the competition and the basics of business planning
• About costing & record keeping
• You as an entrepreneur; The feasibility study
• Your business idea; A marketing plan
• Form of business, Staff, Legal responsibility and insurance; Costing your product and services
• Financial planning and record-keeping; Required start-up capital; Types and sources of start-up capital, or Starting the business
And the organisational and system level topics relevant in the case of FBC:
1. Changes in the world of entrepreneurship
2. New ways of financing
3. New legal forms
4. The importance of agglomeration
5. The role of innovation and an innovative climate
6. Demand and supply analysis
7. The importance of networking and partnerships
8. Understanding partnership opportunities in Sierra Leone
9. Understanding the Business Ecosystem and FBC's role in it
10. Direction, demand and supply in the Business Ecosystem
11. Articulating FBC Business Ecosystems
12. Navigating the Business Ecosystem for innovation and scaling your business
_**Output 4: Enhanced knowledge and skills of 20 participants on enterprising and active teaching methods**_
A maximum total of 22 TMT participants attended the training sessions. From post-course feedback and comments it can be concluded that the majority indicated that they have enhanced knowledge and skills as a result of the training.
The fully online TMT training delivery was in itself a relatively new method for the project partners that required a different training style. The session facilitators were throughout informed by ‘reflective practitioner’ teaching principles and routinely debriefed together after active training to learn from what worked well in the classroom. The TMT team included Sierra Leoneans who understood the local context and worked effectively with the partners in developing good online teaching skills.
_**Output 5: Sharing staff personal experiences and learning**_
During training sessions opportunity was always allowed for questions, discussion and sharing of personal experiences. The conclusions on this planned output should not, however, only be drawn from the formal sessions, as weekly group and individual assignments were addressed through one-to-one online meetings and small group meetings between project partners and facilitators. These entailed not only sharing of experiences, but also discussions about entrepreneurial opportunities and ways to continue the partnerships. During the group assignments an inventory of ongoing entrepreneurial initiatives was established, discussed/analyzed at group level, and shared during formal sessions. It provided a track record to be used to attract funding for the FBC Innovation Hub. These discussions have been continuing post-project.

title.narrative: B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training
B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication
B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)
B.I.4. % of scholarships awarded to women
B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment
B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes

actual.value: The participants commented that they had experienced personal growth as a result of the course – both in terms of acquiring new skills and also attitudes commensurate with entrepreneurial mindsets.
